name: Kepler-348
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-348 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-348 is a star with 1.774999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.36 times its radius. It is located 1892.36 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-348 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-348 b

Kepler-348 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-348.

The mass of Kepler-348 b is 2.65 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-348 b is 1.52 that of Earth. At 2.65 Earth masses, Kepler-348 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-348 c

Kepler-348 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.27 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-348.

The mass of Kepler-348 c is 1.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-348 c is 1.33 that of Earth. At 1.92 Earth masses, Kepler-348 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-348, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
